snippet: North Korea set off a nuclear test on Tuesday, its official news service said, and preliminary estimates suggested it was far larger than the previous two conducted by the North.
abstract: North Korea appears to conduct its third and probably largest nuclear test; if confirmed, the test would be the first under the country's new leader, Kim Jong-un, and an open act of defiance to the Chinese, who urged the young leader not to risk open confrontation by setting off the weapon;  event poses a new challenge for the Obama administration in its effort to keep the country from becoming a full-fledged nuclear power.

byline.original: By DAVID E. SANGER and CHOE SANG-HUN
byline.contributor: David E. Sanger reported from Washington, and Choe Sang-hun reported from Seoul, South Korea. Jane Perlez contributed reporting from Beijing and Hiroko Tabuchi from Tokyo.

lead_paragraph: North Korea set off a nuclear test on Tuesday, its official news service said, and preliminary estimates suggested it was far larger than the previous two conducted by the North.

headline.seo: North Korea Is Suspected of Conducting 3rd Nuclear Test
headline.main: North Korea Confirms It Conducted 3rd Nuclear Test
headline.print_headline: Evidence Points to Nuclear Test  by North Korea

keywords.value: United States Defense and Military Forces
